awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Improving the Undergraduate Chemistry Experience by Green Chemistry, Active-learning, and Peer-led Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at the University of California, Merced, will advance the aims of the HSI Program by increasing undergraduate student interest and success in chemistry.  The project will redesign laboratory courses to use student-guided inquiry and green chemistry, develop a peer-learning environment that builds a sense of community, and develop short videos to complement lower-division chemistry courses. These videos will feature diverse STEM professionals who will connect chemistry concepts learned in the course to how they use these concepts in their current STEM career. Because many students take chemistry courses, this project can contribute to ensuring that a diverse population of students pursue STEM careers.

The project aims to increase student interest, success, and connection to faculty and peers. The project will redesign laboratory courses to enhance student understanding of chemistry content, knowledge of chemistry research, and connection to peers and the broader campus community. The labs will emphasize the environmental implications of chemistry research. Videos that accompany the redesigned labs are expected to increase student knowledge of career paths in chemistry, motivation for chemistry, and student learning and persistence. The videos will be available in English and in the speaker's native language, to foster the development of student STEM identity, in particular for diverse students. Analytics tools available in the learning management system will be used to measure the use of the videos by students.  Finally, peer-led team-learning is expected to improve students' conceptual understanding, grades, attitudes, and retention. Student learning outcomes will be assessed by student grades, pre-post surveys, retention in the major, graduation rates, and by observation of classroom and lab interactions. The duration and frequency of student use of the peer-led opportunities will also be tracked and correlated with surveys of student attitudes. The project videos will be freely available to the broader community, with the goal of disseminating these tools to enhance learning of undergraduate chemistry.  This project seeks to advance understanding of how to support diverse students' success in chemistry and to connect students with STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award led to significant changes in the undergraduate, lower-division course experience for UC Merced’s STEM majors and has created lasting impact in how STEM courses, particularly in chemistry, are delivered at UC Merced. The findings are being shared through faculty interviews across the UC system, through peer-reviewed publications, through presentations at conferences, through talks with administration, and through discussions between faculty at seminars and workshops.

As part of this award, the organic chemistry labs were revised to include a greater focus on green and sustainable chemistry including the development of two new lab experiments that showcased chemistry developed by UCM graduate and undergraduate student researchers. All of the lab assignments were revised to include elements of guided inquiry based learning and a greater focus on data interpretation and analysis. Online prelab modules were developed for all experiments- these include handouts, slides, video links to key techniques, links to online free lab techniques manual, step-by-step instrument instructions including screenshots and photos.  Jupyterlab Python notebooks for analyzing general chemistry lab data have also been developed to expose students to coding concepts, including data interpretation and analysis, early in their undergraduate experience. Jupyterlab Python notebooks were also developed for introducing students to data science and machine learning as applied to chemical data, with these notebooks now being adopted and expanded in an upper division elective course. The grant also supported the development and operation of “The Chem Center,” which provides drop-in peer tutoring and access to course materials such as textbooks and molecular model kits.

The large enrollment organic chemistry lecture courses were transitioned from a traditional lecture to a flipped classroom with problems delivered to students through a clicker app. More than 500 YouTube videos were made covering key topics and full solutions to all in-class problems (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCh4AeI-lSLBGEfNqtg5Bs9w, channel has 3.43k subscribers, 736k views). Detailed study guides were developed for each chapter covered in the two-course sequence. The study guides are broken down by section and include detailed student learning objectives, links to relevant YouTube videos, and suggested practice problems. 

Videos have been created of student interviews and of students demonstrating chemistry lab techniques for general and organic labs, such as titration, filtration, reflux, and chromatography.  Student interviews, as well as other video content, were shared on our newly developed chemistry social media platforms, where resources and content are shared with chemistry students, while also helping to build community. The first round of completed lab technique videos have recently been uploaded to the UC Merced chemistry YouTube channel. We have found that many students feel apprehension regarding the chemistry lab and hope that seeing students, rather than instructors, perform the techniques can reduce anxiety about lab activities, increasing student self-efficacy, performance, persistence, and retention rates.  These videos will be posted online for others to use and will be incorporated into course materials to help prepare students for lab activities so that they can focus more on the concepts during lab time.  

The award has also supported the observation, study, analysis, and publication of peer-reviewed articles focused on active learning and chemistry student perceptions and attitudes, including specific lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic. 

A significant outcome of this award has been the incorporation of peer learning assistants (LAs) into classrooms throughout math and science at UC Merced, where LAs have improved student engagement and confidence while also increasing active learning in the classroom. With this award, the LA program was piloted in general chemistry, and because of its success has now been expanded to organic chemistry, introductory biology, introductory physics, and math.  With NSF support, materials were developed to train all the LAs in pedagogical practices that help them facilitate an active learning classroom environment.  These LAs not only make the class more interactive, they allow students who have been historically marginalized in STEM fields see successful student examples navigating a STEM major, reducing imposter syndrome, and act at mentors to students new to the college experience.

Modified by: Christine Isborn
